task.summary: GObjectWrapper: Calls g_object_ref/g_object_unref when cloning/dropping in RAII style on the associated pointer returned by g_object_new().

ContainerGObject: To make any rust type returnable from Gtk/GObject related APIs, which allow only types registered by GObject system to be returned. For example, to implemented GListModel for GtkListBox.

Replaced `mem::forget(mem::replace(..,..));` with `ptr::write(..,..);`.
Improved comments on test cases.

ListBoxModelGObject: Wraps any type implementing public_interface::ListBoxModel for passing into gtk ffi functions which expects GObjects.
Basic GObject implementation complete. TODO implement GListModel interface.
Renamed GObjectWrapper to GObjectPtrWrapper, as I frequently mix up ContainerGObject and GObjectWrapper.
GObjectPtrWrapper: Fixed a bug which caused to call g_object_unref on wrapped pointer when calling `to_glib_full()`

ListBoxModelGObject: Completed the GObject binding. Added some tests. Tests pass.
Notable things: * item_ptr was unrefed from create_widget function. This caused segfaults. * Unnecessarily wrapping the recieved item_ptr in GObjectPtrWrapper caused the above problem. *** Only wrap "transfer full" pointers in GObjectPtrWrapper. *** We don't want to unref "transfer none" pointers. * `CString::new("foo").unwrap().as_ptr()` is undefined behaviour. The `CString` instance will go out of scope by the end of the expression. Which means, the pointer returned by as_ptr() will be a dangling pointer. This didn't cause any segfault for me yet. But has the potential to do so. Would have wasted hours in the future, had the compiler not pointed out.
The RefcountTestDouble is moved to test_helpers.rs which will be in the next commit.
ContainerGObject: Added a `get(&self) -> &T` method to get an immutable reference to the contained value.
Removed unnecessary imports. The gui based test case is now considered as passed when the window is closed without having a segfault.

Finally, I did it. :) API completed.
Huge thanks goes to Sebastian Dröge (@sdroege), for his guidance. I almost gave up on the entire GObject ecosystem more than once when I got really stuck. Without his help, I would have stopped there.
Here's one of his awesome blog posts that helped me: https://coaxion.net/blog/2017/09/exporting-a-gobject-c-api-from-rust-code-and-using-it-from-c-python-javascript-and-others/
Here's his GObject Subclass library which is really cool but I don't understand it's working completely, yet :) https://github.com/sdroege/gobject-subclass
Thanks to @oknf from Matrix, who also helps people at `gtk-rs` channel in Gitter. Thanks to everyone at gtk-rs and rust-lang in Gitter and #rust, #rust-beginners on Moznet IRC for your help. Rust is a (positively) difficult language to grasp at first. Without the awesome community, it would have been much much harder.
Moved src/gobject_fzn/*.rs to src/*.rs Removed src/gobject_fzn/mod.rs to src/lib.rs
I should really revise the Rust book chapter explaining `use` and `mod` :/
I should really revise the Rust book chapter explaining `use` and `mod` :/
I had mistyped ListModel as ListBoxModel. Fixed that.

MESSAGE.value: GObjectWrapper: Calls g_object_ref/g_object_unref when cloning/dropping in RAII style on the associated pointer returned by g_object_new().

Replaced `mem::forget(mem::replace(..,..));` with `ptr::write(..,..);`.
Improved comments on test cases.

Basic GObject implementation complete. TODO implement GListModel interface.

The `CString` instance will go out of scope by the end of the expression. Which means, the pointer returned by as_ptr() will be a dangling pointer. This didn't cause any segfault for me yet. But has the potential to do so. Would have wasted hours in the future, had the compiler not pointed out.
The RefcountTestDouble is moved to test_helpers.rs which will be in the next commit.

Here's one of his awesome blog posts that helped me: https://coaxion.net/blog/2017/09/exporting-a-gobject-c-api-from-rust-code-and-using-it-from-c-python-javascript-and-others/

Rust is a (positively) difficult language to grasp at first. Without the awesome community, it would have been much much harder.

option.name: LAST_COMMIT_MESSAGE
option.value: I had mistyped ListModel as ListBoxModel. Fixed that.
